Award.AwardTitle: Biomedical Science and Engineering Summer School
Award.AbstractNarration:
This summer research program will train and mentor underrepresented minority students at the University of Connecticut Health Center (UCHC) in interdisciplinary research projects involving biomaterials, stem cells and tissue engineering strategy development for orthopedic as well as craniofacial tissues. The program is designed to provide hands-on research experience and will mentor students in scientific writing, professional development, and general communication skills. The unique structure of the training will allow undergraduate mentees to learn about medical/dental school, while obtaining research training under the guidance of a mentor. The principal investigator has a successful track record of training and mentoring underrepresented minority students and has excellent resources available to him at UCHC that would help the program to be successful.

Through research training and mentoring, the program would enable and encourage URM students to pursue biomedical science, biomedical engineering, and physician and physician scientist careers, which in the long-term could help address workforce diversity issues in the biomedical science/engineering and related fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Biomedical Science and Engineering (BSE) summer school pilot program was to train minority/women students to pursue careers in biomedical sciences and engineering. Under this program, a number of participants received hands-on research experience in biomaterials science and engineering and the development of synthetic grafts for tissue engineering. While doing their individual/team projects, the students received mentoring training, which included scientific writing, porfessional development and research communication skills. The objective of this training are (i) to introduce biomaterials and tissue engineering research at early stage to the biomedical engineering undergraduate students, (ii) to provide basic understanding of research and what it takes to design a research hypothesis and how to go about addressing the hypothesis, and (iii) to train in engineering design and how to come up with design ideas and proto-type development. Key outcomes of this program include  (i) the development of a protocol to form patient-derived and intra-operatively formed biomaterials for tissue engineering, (ii) devicing a method to biomineralize amorphous silica three-dimensional structures, (iii) design and automation of a bench-top high-pressure bioreactor to study the effect of high-pressure oxygen on mesenchymal stem cell survival, proliferation and their osteogenic and chondrogenic differentiation. Overall, the program successfully provided research as well as mentorship training to the BSE summer school participants.
